    > size being wrong. So, this example just goes to show that multiple
    > reporting might be helpful in some circumstances. 
    > Obviously not all,
    > and quite possibly not useful enough for the sizeable and 
    > challenging
    > framework change required to support it.
 
How would this complete list help you any more than the simple fact that the
arrays were not of the same length?  Given that I expected them to contain
the same number of elements, the most valuable information to me would be
that they were of different lengths, not which elements were/were not
present.

As far as what someone else said about working in batch mode, I submit that
trying to fix more than one problem at a time (no matter how good you are)
results in more headaches than trying to fix one at a time.  Some may
disagree...  Even though JUnit users are not all XPers, it is still a good
practice to do the simplest thing that could possibly work, and build from
there -- especially when trying to fix tests!

Respectfully,
-Jason
